Section Text: The patient is a 76-year-old white female presenting for a refill of her blood pressure medication. She has a history of hypertension, osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, hypothyroidism, allergic rhinitis, and kidney stones. She reports no new concerns or changes regarding these issues. She denies fever, chills, cough, congestion, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, or chest pressure.

The patient is a 25-year-old female presenting with the "worst headache of her life" which started suddenly on July 31st around 11 AM. She reports associated symptoms of blurry vision, lightheadedness (described as "blind spots"), and difficulty writing (right-handed but writing looks like left-handed). She also notes facial swelling that started around the same time as the headache. She denies vomiting. In the ER, a thorough exam and evaluation are planned, along with a CT scan, migraine cocktail, and Morphine.

The patient is a 25-year-old female presenting with the "worst headache of her life" which started suddenly yesterday, July 31st, around 11 AM. She reports associated blurry vision, lightheadedness described as "blind spots," and difficulty writing, noting her naturally right-handed writing looks like she's trying with her left hand. She also reports facial swelling that started around the same time as the headache. She denies nausea and vomiting. A CT scan has been ordered, and a migraine cocktail and Morphine are being administered.

The patient is a 25-year-old female presenting with the "worst headache of her life" which started suddenly yesterday, July 31st, at 11 AM. Associated symptoms include blurry vision, lightheadedness described as "blind spots," and difficulty writing, noting her writing looks messy as if she's using her left hand despite being right-handed. She also reports facial swelling that started around the same time as the headache. She denies vomiting. The plan includes a thorough exam and evaluation, CT scan, migraine cocktail, and Morphine.

The patient is a 25-year-old presenting with the "worst headache of my life," which started suddenly yesterday, July 31st, around 11 AM. Associated symptoms include blurry vision, lightheadedness described as "blind spots," and difficulty writing, noting that her right-handed writing looks like she is trying with her left hand. The patient is a 25-year-old female presenting with the "worst headache of her life," which started suddenly yesterday, July 31st, around 11 AM. She also notes facial swelling that began around the same time as the headache. The patient denies vomiting. The doctor plans a CT scan, migraine cocktail, and Morphine.

The patient is a 25-year-old female presenting to the ER with a sudden onset "worst headache of my life" that started yesterday, July 31st, around 11 AM. Associated symptoms include blurry vision, lightheadedness described as "blind spots," and difficulty writing, noting that despite being right-handed her writing is messy "like I am trying with my left." She also reports facial swelling that began around the same time as the headache. She denies nausea and vomiting. The plan includes a CT scan, a migraine cocktail, and Morphine.
